site_name: OUT OF AFRICA WILDLIFE PARK, L L C

citations.narrative:
Multiple surface types in two outdoor enclosures for birds have jagged edges and sharp points that could injure the birds.
An outdoor primary enclosure for 2 adult Emus has a shelter constructed of different materials including corrugated metal
where cut edges are jagged and corners are sharp to the touch. The "Community Aviary" for 1 Blue-and-yellow Macaw, 1
Scarlet Macaw, 2 Helmeted Guineafowl, 5 Ringneck Doves and 1 Red-crested Turaco also has corrugated metal used for
sheltered housing and facility construction that has jagged cut edges and sharp corners. This enclosure also has a metal
wire used as a fastener where the sharp end measuring approximately 2 inches is not secured and sticks out near eye-
level of the ground-dwelling Helmeted Guineafowl. Additionally, there are 4 metal screws located above the entrance
pointing into the enclosure where the sharp ends measure approximately 1/2 inch to 2 inches. Surfaces that have jagged
edges or sharp points with which birds can come into contact may cause them injury.
Interior surfaces and surfaces of housing facilities that come in contact with birds must be free of jagged edges or sharp
points that could injure the birds.
Correct by 20 January 2024.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
A male Scarlet Macaw "Big Bird" who is showing signs of psychological distress in appearance through feather plucking
of the legs and flanks, does not have written documentation of additional environmental enhancement approved by the
attending veterinarian. Failure to address signs of being in psychological distress in birds through additional
environmental enhancement in accordance with attending veterinarian instructions may result in continued or worsening
signs of affected animals.
Certain birds must be provided special attention regarding enhancement of their environment in accordance with the
instructions of the attending veterinarian, including those that show signs of being in psychological distress through
behavior or appearance.
Correct by 20 January 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.150(c)(3) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Multiple surface types in two outdoor enclosures for birds have jagged edges and sharp points that could injure the birds. 
An outdoor primary enclosure for 2 adult Emus has a shelter constructed of different materials including corrugated metal 
where cut edges are jagged and corners are sharp to the touch. The "Community Aviary" for 1 Blue-and-yellow  Macaw, 1 
Scarlet Macaw, 2 Helmeted Guineafowl, 5 Ringneck Doves and 1 Red-crested Turaco also has corrugated metal used for 
sheltered housing and facility construction that has jagged cut edges and sharp corners. This enclosure also has a metal 
wire used as a fastener where the sharp end measuring approximately 2 inches is not secured and sticks out near eye-
level of the ground-dwelling  Helmeted Guineafowl. Additionally, there are 4 metal screws located above the entrance 
pointing into the enclosure where the sharp ends measure approximately 1/2 inch to 2 inches. Surfaces that have jagged 
edges or sharp points with which birds can come into contact may cause them injury.  
 
Interior surfaces and surfaces of housing facilities that come in contact with birds must be free of jagged edges or sharp 
points that could injure the birds.  
Correct by 20 January 2024. 
3.154(c)(2) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
A male Scarlet Macaw "Big Bird" who is showing signs of psychological distress in appearance through feather plucking 
of the legs and flanks, does not have written documentation of additional environmental  enhancement approved  by the 
attending veterinarian.  Failure to address signs of being in psychological distress in birds through additional 
environmental  enhancement in accordance with attending veterinarian  instructions may result in continued or worsening 
signs of affected animals.  
 
Certain birds must be provided  special attention regarding  enhancement of their environment  in accordance with the 
instructions of the attending veterinarian,  including those that show signs of being in psychological distress through 
behavior  or appearance.  
Correct by 20 January 2024.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
